intro: Agapetes adenobotrys, commonly known as the silverleaf agapetes, is a species of flowering plant in the Ericaceae family. It is native to the temperate regions of South America, particularly in the Andes mountains. The plant is characterized by its small, evergreen leaves that are covered in a dense layer of white, woolly hair, giving it a silvery appearance. It produces bell-shaped flowers that are typically pink or white, which bloom in late spring to early summer. Agapetes adenobotrys thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in cloud forests or mountainous areas with cool, humid climates.
